repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: Some copy pasting. I also added an example for python object pointers.

comment_data.body:
Better: "Where C uses ..."
"As" reads like a reason, which is not meant here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -381,6 +381,48 @@ Sometimes Cython will complain unnecessarily, and sometimes it will fail to
 detect a problem that exists. Ultimately, you need to understand the issue and
 be careful what you do.
 
+
+Type Casting
+------------
+
+As C uses the ``"("`` and ``")"`` for casting types, Cython uses ``"<"`` and ``">"``

comment_data.body:
"to signify a casting" - I'd remove these words entirely. Just: "where C uses abc, Cython uses xyz."
Problem is that "a casting" reads badly and is probably not proper English.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -381,6 +381,48 @@ Sometimes Cython will complain unnecessarily, and sometimes it will fail to
 detect a problem that exists. Ultimately, you need to understand the issue and
 be careful what you do.
 
+
+Type Casting
+------------
+
+As C uses the ``"("`` and ``")"`` for casting types, Cython uses ``"<"`` and ``">"``
+to signify a casting. For example::

comment_data.body: I do not understand what this sentence is trying to say.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -381,6 +381,48 @@ Sometimes Cython will complain unnecessarily, and sometimes it will fail to
 detect a problem that exists. Ultimately, you need to understand the issue and
 be careful what you do.
 
+
+Type Casting
+------------
+
+As C uses the ``"("`` and ``")"`` for casting types, Cython uses ``"<"`` and ``">"``
+to signify a casting. For example::
+
+    cdef char *p
+    cdef float *q
+    p = <char*>q
+
+If one of the types is a Python object for ``<type>x``, Cython will try to do a coercion.

comment_data.body: Maybe: "Cython will not prevent a redundant cast, but emits a warning for it." ? Is that what is meant here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -381,6 +381,48 @@ Sometimes Cython will complain unnecessarily, and sometimes it will fail to
 detect a problem that exists. Ultimately, you need to understand the issue and
 be careful what you do.
 
+
+Type Casting
+------------
+
+As C uses the ``"("`` and ``")"`` for casting types, Cython uses ``"<"`` and ``">"``
+to signify a casting. For example::
+
+    cdef char *p
+    cdef float *q
+    p = <char*>q
+
+If one of the types is a Python object for ``<type>x``, Cython will try to do a coercion.
+
+ .. note:: Cython will not stop a casting where there is no conversion, but it will emit a warning.

comment_data.body: "You can also cast a C pointer back to a Python object reference with `<object>`, or a more specific builtin or extension type (e.g. `<MyExtType>ptr`). This will increase the reference count of the object by one, i.e. the cast returns an owned reference."
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -381,6 +381,48 @@ Sometimes Cython will complain unnecessarily, and sometimes it will fail to
 detect a problem that exists. Ultimately, you need to understand the issue and
 be careful what you do.
 
+
+Type Casting
+------------
+
+As C uses the ``"("`` and ``")"`` for casting types, Cython uses ``"<"`` and ``">"``
+to signify a casting. For example::
+
+    cdef char *p
+    cdef float *q
+    p = <char*>q
+
+If one of the types is a Python object for ``<type>x``, Cython will try to do a coercion.
+
+ .. note:: Cython will not stop a casting where there is no conversion, but it will emit a warning.
+
+To get the address of some Python object, use a cast to a pointer type
+like ``<void*>`` or ``<PyObject*>``.
+You can also get the python object from a pointer to this object by doing ``<object>``.

comment_data.body:
Bad example since this is not portable. Pointers do not necessarily fit into the size of a `long`, e.g. on Win64.
You can cimport `uintptr_t` from `libc.stdint`, though, and use that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -381,6 +381,48 @@ Sometimes Cython will complain unnecessarily, and sometimes it will fail to
 detect a problem that exists. Ultimately, you need to understand the issue and
 be careful what you do.
 
+
+Type Casting
+------------
+
+As C uses the ``"("`` and ``")"`` for casting types, Cython uses ``"<"`` and ``">"``
+to signify a casting. For example::
+
+    cdef char *p
+    cdef float *q
+    p = <char*>q
+
+If one of the types is a Python object for ``<type>x``, Cython will try to do a coercion.
+
+ .. note:: Cython will not stop a casting where there is no conversion, but it will emit a warning.
+
+To get the address of some Python object, use a cast to a pointer type
+like ``<void*>`` or ``<PyObject*>``.
+You can also get the python object from a pointer to this object by doing ``<object>``.
+Here is an example::
+
+    from __future__ import print_function
+    from cpython.ref cimport PyObject
+
+    python_string = "foo"
+
+    cdef void* ptr = <void*>python_string
+    cdef long adress_in_c = <long>ptr

comment_data.body:
I think what it means is this:
"When casting a C value to a Python object type or vice versa, Cython will attempt a coercion."
Then, to give an example, I'd add:
"Simple examples are casts like ``<int>pyobj``, which converts a Python number to a plain C ``int`` value, or ``<bytes>charptr``, which copies a C ``char*`` string into a new Python ``bytes`` object."

+    cdef char *p
+    cdef float *q
+    p = <char*>q
+
+If one of the types is a Python object for ``<type>x``, Cython will try to do a coercion.

comment_data.body: Thanks, the reference guide isn't always easy to understand.

commit.message: switching long for uintptr_t, and rephrasing some parts.
